pt: {sc}talkative{/sc} {sc}loquacious{/sc} {sc}garrulous{/sc} {sc}voluble{/sc} mean given to talk or talking. {sc}talkative{/sc} may imply a readiness to engage in talk or a disposition to enjoy conversation.
{sc}loquacious{/sc} suggests the power of expressing oneself articulately, fluently, or glibly.
{sc}garrulous{/sc} implies prosy, rambling, or tedious loquacity.
{sc}voluble{/sc} suggests a free, easy, and unending loquacity.

et: Middle English {it}volible, voluble{/it} "able to turn, changing," borrowed from Latin {it}volūbilis{/it} "turning on its axis, rolling, flowing, (of speech) readily flowing, fluent," from {it}volū-,{/it} variant stem of {it}volvere{/it} "to set in a circular course, cause to roll" + {it}-bilis{/it} "capable (of acting) or worthy (of being acted upon)" {ma}{mat|wallow:1|}, {mat|-able|}{/ma}
shortdef: characterized by ready or rapid speech : glib, fluent
